p: These initiatives express the deepening of corporate food regime power—beyond simply a license to profit from organized liberalization of foreign trade and investment by food companies and financial interests. Now states partner collectively, through alliances or UN membership, to mobilize public resources and reframe land and agricultural policy in the name of productivity, food marketing, and green practices to be managed by transnational food corporations. Most importantly, the notion of the ‘public good’ is undergoing reformulation via discursive legitimation, as best served by private interest.
